_comment_what_is_this: This file defines the Node.js application metadata and dependencies. It's like a manifest that tells npm (Node Package Manager) what libraries this application needs and how to run it.
_comment_used_by: npm install, npm start, Docker build process
name: enterprise-metrics-app
_comment_name: Application name - used for identification and npm registry if published. Must be lowercase with hyphens, no spaces.
_comment_version: Semantic versioning (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Format: 1.0.0 means: major version 1, minor version 0, patch 0. Increment MAJOR for breaking changes, MINOR for new features, PATCH for bug fixes.
description: Enterprise application with built-in Prometheus metrics
_comment_description: Human-readable description of what this application does. Shows up in npm search and documentation.
_comment_main: Entry point file - the first file Node.js executes when running this application. This is where our Express server and metrics are defined.

scripts._comment_scripts_purpose: Custom commands that can be run with 'npm run <script-name>'
scripts._comment_scripts_usage: Scripts automate common tasks like starting the server, running tests, or building the application.
scripts._comment_start: START SCRIPT - Runs when you execute 'npm start'. This is the command Docker uses to start our application. 'node server.js' tells Node.js to execute the server.js file.

dependencies._comment_dependencies_purpose: Required packages for the application to run
dependencies._comment_dependencies_install: These are installed when you run 'npm install'
dependencies._comment_dependencies_production: These must be included in production deployments
dependencies._comment_dependencies_note: Version format: ^4.18.2 means >= 4.18.2 but < 5.0.0 (caret allows minor and patch updates)
dependencies._comment_express: EXPRESS WEB FRAMEWORK - Fast, minimalist web framework for Node.js. Provides: HTTP server, routing (/api/users), middleware (logging, auth), request/response handling. Why? Makes building REST APIs and web servers much easier than using raw Node.js http module. Without Express, we'd need 10x more code. Official: https://expressjs.com
dependencies._comment_prom_client: PROMETHEUS CLIENT LIBRARY - Official Prometheus client for Node.js. Provides: Metric types (Counter, Gauge, Histogram, Summary), Default Node.js metrics (CPU, memory, GC), Prometheus text format exporter. Why? This is what makes our app 'Prometheus-ready'. It handles all the complexity of metric formatting and collection. Without this, we'd have to manually format metrics in Prometheus text format (very tedious!). Official: https://github.com/siimon/prom-client. This is the CORE library that enables direct scraping without needing an exporter.

_comment_dev_dependencies_note: We don't have devDependencies in this project because it's a simple demo. In a real project, you'd have: 'devDependencies': { 'eslint': '^8.0.0' (code linting), 'jest': '^29.0.0' (testing), 'nodemon': '^3.0.0' (auto-restart during development) }. DevDependencies are NOT installed in production (Docker uses --production flag).
_final_note_2: 1. Developer runs 'npm install' → npm reads dependencies → downloads express and prom-client
_final_note_3: 2. Docker build runs 'npm install --production' → installs only dependencies (not devDependencies)
_final_note_4: 3. Docker starts container with 'npm start' → executes 'node server.js' → server starts on port 3000
_final_note_5: 4. Application is now running and exposing /metrics endpoint for Prometheus
_final_note_lock_file: When you run 'npm install', npm also creates package-lock.json which locks EXACT versions of all dependencies (including sub-dependencies). This ensures consistent installs across different machines. Always commit package-lock.json to version control!
_final_note_json_format: This file is in JSON format, which means these _comment fields are technically not standard. In a real project, you'd put comments in a separate README.md. But for learning purposes, these inline comments explain each field.
_final_note_package_managers: npm is the default Node.js package manager. Alternatives: yarn (faster, created by Facebook), pnpm (more efficient disk usage). All work with package.json, just different install commands.
